user_message:
Target function code is:
```c
static bool
get_nonce_timestamp (const char *const nonce,
                     size_t noncelen,
                     uint64_t *const ptimestamp)
{
  if (0 == noncelen)
    noncelen = strlen (nonce);

  if (true
#ifdef MHD_MD5_SUPPORT
      && (NONCE_STD_LEN (MD5_DIGEST_SIZE) != noncelen)
#endif /* MHD_MD5_SUPPORT */
#if defined(MHD_SHA256_SUPPORT) || defined(MHD_SHA512_256_SUPPORT)
      && (NONCE_STD_LEN (SHA256_SHA512_256_DIGEST_SIZE) != noncelen)
#endif /* MHD_SHA256_SUPPORT */
      )
    return false;

  if (TIMESTAMP_CHARS_LEN !=
      MHD_strx_to_uint64_n_ (nonce + noncelen - TIMESTAMP_CHARS_LEN,
                             TIMESTAMP_CHARS_LEN,
                             ptimestamp))
    return false;
  return true;
}
```

Static call graph of the target function is:



List additional symbols that are required to analyze the target function to determine if the target function code violates the following MISRA C rule:
A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible. 
The list will be included in the prompt for the next agent, so be concise and clear.
Explain why each symbol is required in the analysis of the target function for the MISRA C rule.
explanation:
MHD_strx_to_uint64_n_: The target function forwards ptimestamp to this routine. To determine whether ptimestamp must be a pointer-to-non-const (i.e. whether the pointee is modified) you must inspect the prototype and implementation of MHD_strx_to_uint64_n_ (parameter types and any writes through that pointer).

toxdigitvalue: MHD_strx_to_uint64_n_ calls this helper; if that helper (or other callees) ever write to the uint64_t pointed-to value (directly or indirectly) that affects whether ptimestamp can be made a pointer-to-const. Include it only if needed when inspecting MHD_strx_to_uint64_n_.

check_nonce_nc, is_slot_available, digest_auth_check_all_inner: These are callers of get_nonce_timestamp. To decide whether ptimestamp could/should be const-qualified you must inspect call sites to see how callers pass and use the address argument (e.g. whether they expect the function to write an output value). If callers depend on a written result, the pointee cannot be const.

TIMESTAMP_CHARS_LEN: This macro controls the length argument and pointer arithmetic used when passing nonce + noncelen - TIMESTAMP_CHARS_LEN to MHD_strx_to_uint64_n_. While not directly about const-qualification, confirming the exact length and pointer arithmetic helps verify which memory slice is passed and whether any aliasing/overlap concerns affect whether the pointee should be const.
